transformed_texts:
I think the Catholic Church needs to modernize its views in a few ways. They've been talking about losing followers, and I think it's because they aren't very accepting of many things.  For example, they have strong opinions on gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which are fine, but those views seem a bit outdated. If they were more open-minded, maybe they wouldn't worry about losing people. I've heard that some people are turning away from the Catholic Church because of their stance on these issues. They feel the Church is wrong on certain subjects.  

For example, if you believe in abortion rights, you might not feel comfortable in a church that teaches it's completely wrong. It's the same with gay marriage. If you support it, you might not want to be part of a church that doesn't.

I don't see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to be married.  It's hard to say if those changes would have prevented the recent scandals, though. Maybe they would have, maybe not.  

It seems unfair that priests are expected to be completely devoted to God while everyone else gets to have both a job and a family.  Why can't priests have both?

I'm not against gay marriage. I think it's wrong to judge someone for who they love.  Whether someone is born that way or it develops over time, it's not a choice they make, so they shouldn't be held responsible for their sexual orientation. It just doesn't seem fair to say that a man and a woman can get married but two people of the same sex can't.  

Honestly, I haven't really thought about it too much, but it feels wrong to me.  It's like being born straight versus being born gay – you don't choose either one.

I don't think the federal government should get involved. It's not a legal issue, and I don't know if it's even a moral issue. It just feels like the government shouldn't be telling people who they can and can't love.  

It's not like gay people are doing something wrong or making a bad choice. They are who they are, and they shouldn't be treated any differently.

So, I really think gay marriage should be legal. Honestly, I don't see a good reason against it. Some folks worry that gay couples are a threat to traditional families, but that just doesn't make sense to me. It's like comparing apples and oranges – they're both fruits, but totally different. 

Plus, there are tons of important civil rights tied to marriage, like healthcare and property rights. If you're in a gay relationship, your partner might not be able to be with you in the hospital or make medical decisions if you're sick, because they're not legally recognized as family.  Seems unfair, right?

And studies show that gay couples are just as happy and successful as straight couples. It's all about love and commitment.  

What really gets me is that people think gay couples are asking for special treatment. They're not trying to get married in a church; they just want the legal recognition and protections that come with a marriage certificate. If the government's not involved in church matters, why should religion dictate who can and can't get married?

It's like segregation – separate but unequal. 

And let's talk about adoption and kids. Some folks worry about how gay parents will raise their kids, but honestly, good parenting comes down to love and support, not sexual orientation. 

The truth is, some kids of gay parents face bullying and discrimination. It's heartbreaking.  

I think the federal government needs to step up and make gay marriage legal everywhere. We need to treat everyone equally. We can't let religious beliefs dictate the law and deny people their basic rights.

Okay, so I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer, and it makes me think about this whole marijuana thing. Just because something's illegal doesn't automatically mean it's bad. I mean, there are tons of drugs we use in pharmacies that are illegal for the general public, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet, you know? Those are all controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they have medical benefits.  It feels wrong to say marijuana is totally off-limits just because it has a bad reputation.

I get that some people worry about marijuana being abused, just like alcohol.  But honestly, I think we need to ditch the whole "marijuana is the devil" image. It's not as harmful as heroin or cocaine. If we stopped seeing it as this scary, dangerous drug, people might be more likely to use it responsibly, especially for medical reasons.


Maybe we should try legalizing it gradually, not all at once. That way, we can make sure people are using it safely.

I think the church has definitely changed to be more modern. It's not as strict as it used to be. When I was younger, I went to church every Sunday, always dressed up in cute dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. I went to a private school and saw all my friends there on the weekends. But now, as I've gotten older, they've created a special mass for teenagers that's only thirty minutes long. People dress much more casually now, especially in the summer. You'll see people in their beach clothes, straight from the beach, or families running in late. Even at the morning masses, where I used to always get dressed up, people wear jeans and khakis. It's definitely more casual overall.  That's the biggest change I've noticed.

As for other changes, that's the biggest thing that stands out to me. That's the church I know. I don't know much about the politics of the church, but that's just my experience. 

About those accusations against Catholic priests, I don't think allowing female priests or letting priests marry would have stopped them. There are married men who become pedophiles too, and they still have attractions to young children.  I think it's about the individual, not whether or not they're allowed to get married. Becoming a priest is a choice, and there are other religions where priests can be married. If someone really wants to practice their faith and be married, they should maybe consider a different religion.

I think pedophilia is often genetic. I don't think people just become that way. It's something they're born with. It might have something to do with upbringing in some cases, but I think genetics play a big role. You can't hide that with marriage. You may try, but it usually comes out eventually. I don't think the church could have prevented this from happening. If they knew about it and tried to cover it up, then shame on them. But I don't think they always knew.

Honestly, I'm still bothered by the whole Iraq War thing. Sure, at first, I kinda understood it, everyone was on edge after 9/11, but I think we rushed into it for the wrong reasons. The Bush administration kept saying it was all about Bin Laden and Saddam Hussein having weapons of mass destruction, but we later found out that was a bunch of lies. That really rubs me the wrong way.  It feels like they straight-up lied to the American people, and they haven't even admitted it. Even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN, has since said he wasn't convinced by the evidence back then.  That's just wrong, in my opinion. It's like they don't care about the Constitution or anything. 

I get the feeling they wanted to go to war from the start. Remember that Treasury Secretary who wrote a book after he was basically pushed out of his job? He said the younger Bush came in wanting revenge against Saddam Hussein because of what happened with his dad. Plus, I think they were hoping to secure our energy supply, which is pretty shady.

Look, I think it's gone on long enough. Pulling out right now would probably cause chaos with a civil war breaking out and even more people dying. But bringing in other countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to help out? That doesn't seem like a good solution either. It's going to mess with Iraq's sovereignty, and honestly, I don't think their government is working anyway. The Parliament seems useless, and the Prime Minister doesn't really have any power. And don't even get me started on that extremist group, the one we were fighting not too long ago. They're now in Parliament with a bunch of seats. It's all so complicated, and I don't have all the answers.

I'm not sure exactly how I feel about the war in Iraq.  It feels pointless, like it was just a way for us to get back at them for 9/11. I don't really follow the news about it, so I don't know all the details.  But my understanding is we're trying to build democracy there, kind of like making it another part of the US, and also to get access to their oil. But staying there just makes everyone upset.  

Building a democracy takes a long time, and if we leave they'll be angry because they feel like we messed things up and abandoned them.  It's a tough situation.

Honestly, this whole thing is really complicated. I don't know if it's right to keep sending our troops there, even though it's important to help those people. It feels like we're wasting our resources, and it's making President Bush look bad. We're starting to sound like we're just trying to show off our strength and power, like the Vietnam War.  

I also think about the families of the soldiers who are in Iraq. I want them to come home safely, but I also worry about the people of Iraq and the impact of our presence on their lives and culture. 

What if we're just making things worse by trying to force our ideas on them? Maybe it's best to leave and let them find their own way, even if it's painful. This whole war seems like it's going to drag on for years and years. I just don't know what the right answer is.

I don't think it's right for the government to make it legal or for a state to declare it legal. It should be up to the churches because the Constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any kind of power over it would be going against what's already been written in stone. So, I think those trying to make it illegal are basically choosing one church's beliefs over another, because most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for maybe in some areas like Boston. 

Separation of church and state is a key part of the Constitution, allowing for religious tolerance in the United States. Even though they're thinking about making an amendment, I think it would be wrong and go against what's already been established. Plus, it would be one of the few amendments that restricts people instead of the government. I just don't think it's right.

I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. I don't understand why someone would push for this amendment unless it's because it goes against their personal beliefs as a Catholic. It seems like they're favoring one religion over others. I really feel it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government officials. There isn't a good reason for an amendment banning it, other than personal views. I don't see how it would negatively impact the economy or anything else. It might even be positive for society.

Ok, so the war in Iraq. To be honest, I don't think the government was completely upfront with the American people about the reasons we went to war. Before invading, they tried to link it to the 9/11 attacks, but really, the two weren't that connected.  But the government played on people's emotions after 9/11,  and that's how the invasion of Iraq started in 2003.

Personally, I'm against war, especially preemptive strikes. And I think this war in Iraq feels a lot like the Vietnam War. We should have learned from past mistakes. So many American soldiers have died, and it's horrible. I think the government wasn't prepared for the chaos that would follow removing the Iraqi government. They weren't ready for the power vacuum and the unrest.

It's like what happened in Vietnam – we tried to push out Communism and install democracy, and it was a long, hard struggle. We should have known it wouldn't be a quick victory. In Vietnam, no matter how many people supported us, there were always insurgents. It's hard to fight a war against your own people.

So, first, I think we shouldn't have gone to war at all. But if we're going to, we need to plan for everything. I don't think the government was prepared for what would happen after removing the Iraqi government.  We're still there in 2006, and American troops are still dying. We're trying to train the Iraqi police and army, but it's a slow process.

I think the government tried to make it seem like it would be a quick, successful mission. But it takes years to build a new government.  Look at our own country – democracy took a long time to develop.  It wasn't easy.


I think the government made it seem like it would be easy to change Iraq. 

It's hard because we've been there so long. How can we just abandon them now after taking their government and way of life? But we also have to consider the cost in American lives. How many is too many?  

Another thing that bothers me is why Iraq? Why not other countries? I think it's all about oil. That's where our resources are. They said Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but they were never found. But we know North Korea has them, and we're not doing anything about it. I don't think the government is being truthful about its reasons for going to war.  

I just hope it ends soon and there's peace. But I'm not sure that'll happen.

Okay, so, I'm totally for gay marriage. Always have been.  I really think it's a personal choice, and it's becoming more and more clear that it might even be biological, not just something about how you were raised.  So, to take away someone's rights based on something they can't control just seems wrong to me.  It feels kind of inhumane.  I've always been a supporter of gay marriage.

I don't think politics or the government should have anything to do with it. It's a personal thing, something that affects families and individuals, not the state. You know, in my neighborhood, there are a couple of openly gay couples who aren't married because they can't be. They live their lives just like any other family though - walking their dogs, hanging out, you know? 

It just seems ridiculous to me that someone like Bush wants to define marriage in his own way. It's like he's playing God. 

I've read and heard a lot about how being gay might be linked to something in your brain, like a biological predisposition. It's not about growing up with certain siblings or a lack of a father figure, it's more about something you're born with.

Besides the obvious reason, it's just that marriage is something a guy and a girl can do secretly if they want to. But if two gay people want to get married, it becomes a huge deal, like front-page news. It should be a private matter, not something the whole country is involved in.

Okay, so basically, when you put something online, it's out there for everyone to see. It's public knowledge.  As a resident advisor, I've actually dealt with this before.  

What you post online can definitely shape how people perceive you. If you're talking about violence, like blowing things up or shootings, someone is going to take notice. You can't just put that out into the world. The internet reaches everyone. If you're friends with someone on MySpace, you get their updates. The school wouldn't have gotten a bulletin directly; someone went to the school with this information. They had to act on it because they can't just ignore it, especially after something like 9/11.  You don't want them to be unprepared if something were to happen.

However, it's tough to know what to take seriously because some people might just be joking around. Maybe it was a social experiment gone wrong for a class, or maybe it was something really serious.  

In one situation at our school, someone overheard a conversation and reported it. When they finally found the person, they looked through his Facebook and found some things that seemed harmless but became concerning given the situation.

The point is, once you put something online, there's no real privacy anymore. If you don't want it out there, don't post it. If you don't want people to see it or interpret it a certain way, you can't control that.
Schools shouldn't be friends with their students on social media and snooping through their profiles, but if something is brought to their attention, they have to take it seriously.  They shouldn't be monitoring phone conversations or texts, but if it's brought to their attention, that's a different story.

I feel like the war has dragged on for way too long. Sure, the initial goal of spreading democracy to a country lacking it seemed good at the start. But, honestly, I think we've lost sight of that original purpose. Now, it feels like we're just fighting for the sake of fighting, trying to prove how powerful we are. I also wonder about the motives behind the war in the first place. There were those old conflicts between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein, so maybe that played a part.  I mean, if the goal was truly to bring democracy to a country under a terrible leader, that would be a justifiable reason for war. But if personal grudges were involved, then that wouldn't be right. 

Regardless, the war has gone on for far too long. We made our point in those first few months when we launched the invasion. It was a powerful statement.  But it's been years now, and I think it's time to end it.  Maybe we were right to start the war, but I don't think our reasons have stayed clear. It feels like we're stuck in a never-ending conflict, just trying to win at all costs. 

It's just not right to keep fighting this war forever. These people need to learn to govern themselves eventually, and that time is now. We've been pouring billions of dollars into this war while we have so many problems here at home. Poverty, infrastructure, healthcare—these are things that need our attention and resources. It's a huge drain on our economy, and it's happening for a cause that we've long since lost sight of.  

We need to stop spending billions on war and start investing in our own country. There are so many pressing issues that need our attention, and this war is just dragging us down.

So, I'm curious about this situation. Was it stopped because someone stumbled upon information online?  Okay, so I don't think that's an invasion of privacy. On sites like Myspace, if you post something, it's pretty much out there for everyone to see. Sure, you need to be friends with someone to view their profile, but you're basically giving them permission to see it when you add them as a friend.  Honestly, anything you put online should be seen as public knowledge. So, I think it's good that someone saw that information and was able to prevent something bad from happening.

It's tough though because you can't have someone constantly watching everyone's profiles to prevent problems. It would be discriminatory to target "bad kids" and focus on them. I don't think it's right to have someone's job be to constantly monitor people's online activity. It depends on the situation though. Were they randomly looking at profiles, or were they specifically searching for evidence of something? I just don't know.

I don't have Myspace personally, but I do have Facebook. It does worry me that there are creepy people out there who can see all sorts of things about me. I saw a news story about a guy who easily found a girl's screen name and started IMing her, arranging to meet her within minutes. Obviously, I wouldn't meet someone like that, but I've had people in my classes message me on IM who I don't recognize. They know my interests, what I look like, and even my class schedule. They know a lot about you from your profile. I try to be careful about what I share, but it's hard because I want to connect with friends. It's a tough balance.  You have to be careful who you let see your stuff.

My roommate told me about her high school banning Myspace. I didn't understand how they had the right to tell students what they could and couldn't do online. It felt a bit strange to me.

I feel kinda hypocritical talking about the Iraq War, you know?  I hate jumping on the bandwagon of people who say they were always against it.  I mean, it's pretty obvious now that it was a bad idea, except for the people in charge who don't want to admit they were wrong.  You can see it in the polls.  Everywhere you look, from the US to Iraq to the rest of the world, people think it was a mistake.  Even most of the US troops over there think it was a bad idea and want us to leave. 

Honestly, it's been a mess from the start.  Even before we invaded, things were bad, and now getting out is just going to be another disaster.  

It all comes down to the clash between American culture and the Middle East. The gap is just too big.  Our leaders think they can force democracy on a place where it doesn't fit.  

Sure, Saddam Hussein was a bad guy, but invading a country should never be taken lightly. It's like quicksand - once you're in, it's hard to get out.

I don't know what to say about it.  I don't see any good reason to stay there.  The administration probably has some ideas, but I haven't heard anything convincing.

If they want to leave gradually over a year or so, I guess I could understand that.  But I just don't see why we can't leave now.  Eighty percent of Iraqis want us gone this year, and a quarter want us to leave immediately.  They're the ones we're trying to help, and they're telling us to go. Maybe they know best.

At least if we ask them and they say yes, it's not on us if things go wrong. We can say we were willing to stay, but they chose to leave.  

It won't make us heroes, but it's better than where we are now.

Yeah, I definitely think gender discrimination is still a problem in the United States. And it's not just about women. It really depends on the field you're in. For example, women still face a "glass ceiling" where, even though equality is supposed to be a reality, they often find it hard to get promoted to higher positions. Men might be less likely to work under a woman because of how society has always been. 

So, a woman might have all the qualifications for a job, but the board might not choose her simply because historically, women haven't been in leadership roles in business. It's the same for men, though. Like in fields like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent, there are expectations based on gender.

It's uncommon for a male to stay at home while his wife works, and people sometimes judge them for it. Society thinks the man should be the breadwinner, even if it's not what works best for the family.

And in the fashion industry, straight men sometimes get dismissed as not being serious about fashion because society stereotypes men in the industry as having a certain lifestyle. People might wonder if they really understand fashion if they don't fit that stereotype.

Basically, depending on the field, there is definitely gender discrimination in the U.S. Changing it is tough because society has these ingrained ideas. We've come a long way since the 1800s, but change is slow.

The good news is that things are slowly getting better. More women are becoming CEOs and being accepted in business. More stay-at-home dads are accepted because people see that it works for some families. And maybe people in fashion are starting to realize that men can have valid opinions about fashion too.

I think the key is to keep promoting the positive qualities of people who are stereotyped. We can't force change, but if we highlight the strengths of those who are often overlooked, it will help shift attitudes.  We've already come so far, and with time, things will continue to improve.

So, they didn't actually make marijuana legal.  They decriminalized it, meaning it's no longer a criminal offense.  Think of it like a traffic ticket instead of a serious arrest. You get cited, but you don't get booked or thrown in jail.

Now, even though it's decriminalized, there are still worries about the long-term effects on things like job interviews. Those are the scary parts of a drug charge that don't disappear just because it's not a criminal offense anymore.

But, there's a financial aspect too. Arresting, booking, and processing people for marijuana offenses is incredibly expensive. There are court costs, public defenders, and state attorney fees. It all adds up!

For towns struggling financially, that cost is a big deal. Some places are just against marijuana, even if it would save them money.

But in places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it makes sense to decriminalize it. Maybe they can use that saved money on schools, social programs, or helping the homeless.

It's important to remember that we don't want marijuana openly sold everywhere, like cigarettes.  That could lead to more people smoking and driving, and it's still considered taboo in many situations.

As for the effects, alcohol probably messes with your motor skills more, but marijuana can really mess with your life in other ways. They both have their downsides, and everyone reacts differently. Some people can handle things in moderation, while others struggle.

I'd say yes, because a lot of Catholic traditions are very old and they've been practiced for a long time.  It's good to have those traditions, but it's also important to be open to change.  A lot of Catholics feel like they have to go to church every week and there are strict rules about how things are done. Sometimes, it feels like the Catholic Church judges people who don't follow the rules exactly and doesn't accept people who aren't perfect Catholics or people of other religions.  For example, my dad was an Episcopalian and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't let them get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. That doesn't seem very accepting of other faiths.  We were always taught to love others, which is a Catholic belief, but it feels hypocritical to say that and then not accept people in that way.

It seems like Catholic teachings encourage certain things, but the way things are actually practiced often goes against those teachings because they're so old-fashioned. They just stick with them anyway.

I don't think allowing priests to marry would necessarily change things. I personally think it would be a good idea, but I don't think it would stop priests who are abusive. It's a different problem. It might help a little, but I'm not sure.

It's hard to say, but I think people who abuse children would probably still do it even if they were married. It's about the power dynamic and the abuse itself, not about whether or not someone is married.  I don't think allowing priests to marry would prevent this kind of abuse. It would probably still happen.

Okay, so I'm still figuring this whole thing out. I haven't decided where I stand on this issue yet. It's really tough to say if either side is right or wrong because it's such a complicated topic. It's right on the edge of separation of church and state, and figuring out what marriage really means is super tricky without upsetting anyone. I don't know, but I think maybe civil unions are the way to go. It makes me wonder if the government should even be defining marriage, especially since it's considered a sacred thing by some. After all, the government doesn't give tax breaks or special treatment to people just because they were baptized, right? So maybe marriage should just be seen as a civil union – two people coming together. It's about their commitment to each other, not about the government getting involved in their religious beliefs.

And about gay marriage... I think it gets complicated because it ties into all this stuff about separation of church and state. If it's a civil union, it should be treated the same as any other, regardless of who's involved.

If all the states could agree on a fair solution, maybe they could push for it to become federal law. But trying to ban gay marriage with a constitutional amendment? That seems totally overboard. It just feels wrong to change the Constitution just for this.  It's a big deal for some people, but is it really big enough to warrant a constitutional amendment? I don't think so.

I grew up in a Christian household, so my views on homosexuality are a bit complicated.  I have lots of gay friends, but I'm not sure I personally agree with that lifestyle. However, I think it should be legal.  I don't think it's something the whole country should be arguing about. I feel like each state should decide for themselves instead of leaving it up to the president.

You see, some states are more liberal, and others are more conservative. Democratic states are more likely to support gay marriage, and if you live in one of those states, it makes sense that you'd accept their stance on the issue. Choosing to live in a certain state means accepting their values, right?

I believe everyone, regardless of sexual orientation, should have the same opportunities. So, for that reason, I think gay marriage should be legal, but it should be up to each state to decide.

I don't think the president should be able to make that call for the whole country. It's not fair for him to impose his views on everyone.  He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't get to decide how each one is run.  Plus, he's leaving office soon anyway!  If a new president comes in and wants to overturn the ban, it'll just create more back-and-forth. It's much simpler if each state makes its own choice – they're the ones who will have to live with the consequences.

So, I don't think it's a big deal that school officials checked out what students posted on Myspace. I mean, Myspace is public, right? It's like a bulletin board for everyone to see.  If you put something on there, you have to realize that people will see it, even if it's not your parents or friends. That includes school officials, even if they're not looking at it under the school's name. They could easily see it from their own homes.  

Look, preventing school shootings is super important. Keeping students safe is a big responsibility for schools, and if looking at Myspace helps them do that, then I'm okay with it.  

Now, I get that it can feel like an invasion of privacy if teachers are constantly checking Myspace just to catch kids doing something wrong. Like, if they're digging through profiles looking for evidence of drinking or smoking, that's different. But if they have a reason to believe something is wrong and they use Myspace to investigate, I think that's fair.  

Think about it: If you post something online, even an email, you have to be careful because it can come back to haunt you later. Everything you put out there stays out there forever.  

It's like a teacher told me - they have to do these things to keep the school safe. They have to be prepared for anything, just like they practice lockdown drills in case of a terrorist attack. It's all about making sure everyone stays safe.

Okay, so, about the war... At first, I was all for it because 9/11 hit me personally. I wanted payback, you know? I thought going over there and causing as much trouble as they did here was the right thing to do. Looking back, I think we let our emotions get the best of us. We rushed into it unprepared, without a real plan. It feels like everything backfired. 

Honestly, I was all for it at the time, but now I'm completely against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I feel like as long as they're fighting amongst themselves, they won't be focusing on us.  

Being over there isn't helping; it just seems like a pointless mess. Because of 9/11, I just don't care about what happens over there anymore. It's hard to even think of those people as human, the way they fight and can't seem to get along.

We went in there totally blind; we didn't know what we were facing.  Their idea of war is so different from ours. They're savage, and I don't think they want to build a better country; they just want us out.

Maybe we should just leave. I think we were more hyped up than rational. We didn't think about the consequences or how they would react to us trying to change everything. It felt like we were looking for revenge, and President Bush just went along with it because people wanted it after 9/11.

I get where he was coming from, though. After what happened, we couldn't just ignore it. But I think we could have had a better plan. We weren't clear about what we were trying to achieve, and there was no unity. We didn't know what we were getting into.

It seems like everything was driven by emotion and anger, and that's what we created over there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change them. I think they'll always be like that. I don't know what else to say. It's gone on long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. We've made some, but it's not enough to justify staying. I think no matter how long we're there, it'll collapse when we leave. We can't stay forever. I think we're hurting ourselves by staying.

transformed_texts:
I think the Catholic Church needs to update some of its views. I've heard they're losing followers, and I think it might be because they're not very accepting of things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. The Church has strong beliefs on these issues, which is fine, but their stance feels a bit outdated. If they were more open to modern thinking, maybe they wouldn't be worried about losing people.  

I've heard people are turning away from the Church because they disagree with their views on these topics.  It's understandable that someone who supports abortion or gay marriage wouldn't feel comfortable in a community that condemns those things.  

Personally, I don't see why they couldn't have female priests or allow priests to get married. It seems unfair that they're expected to be completely devoted to God while everyone else has a family life outside of work.

Okay, so, I'm not against gay marriage. I think, like, whether you're born that way or whatever, sexuality isn't something you choose. So, I don't think we should blame people for how they are attracted to others. You know, it seems unfair to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't.

I haven't really thought about it too hard, but I definitely think it's wrong to deny them that right. It just doesn't seem like a choice, like how some people are born straight and others gay.  It's just how they are.

I don't think the government should get involved either. It's not really a legal or moral issue. It's just about people being who they are. It's not like they're making a bad choice or something.

It just feels wrong to make them feel like they're doing something wrong. They shouldn't be treated differently just because of who they love.  It's not like it affects anyone else's safety or anything. It's just their personal lives.

I think gay marriage should be legal. There's really no good reason not to legalize it. Some folks worry that gay couples threaten traditional families, but I think it's totally different. It's like two sides of the same coin – they're not the same, but they're connected. 

There are also tons of civil rights issues tied to it. For example, if you're in a same-sex relationship, your partner might not be allowed to make medical decisions for you if you're sick, or even visit you in the hospital. It just doesn't seem right if you're planning to spend your life with someone.

Plus, lots of studies show that gay relationships are just as successful as straight relationships. They have the same ingredients for a happy partnership.

Really, it's about marriage certificates and legal rights, not church weddings. If the government keeps religion out of it, there shouldn't be a problem.

It's kind of like segregation – separate but unequal.

People worry about things like adoption and how a gay couple living in their community will affect everyone. They also wonder how children of gay couples will adjust.

But honestly, it's mostly new territory. Parenting skills are the same for everyone, whether they're gay or straight.

I think the federal government should get involved and make same-sex marriage legal in all states.  President Bush seems to have really strong religious views against it, which might be linked to his stance on abortion and stem cell research.  

But I think it's important to remember that morality is different for everyone.  Just because some religious groups oppose gay marriage doesn't mean the government should enforce their beliefs on everyone. 

Some people believe being gay is a psychological problem caused by childhood trauma or a personality flaw. But the American Psychological Association says that's just not true. 

We should listen to experts and research instead of just believing what's popular or what our friends tell us.

Okay, so I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer, and I've learned a thing or two.  Just because something is illegal doesn't automatically mean it's bad.  Take drugs, for instance.  I mean, making them available to the public?  Absolutely not.  But using them for medical reasons?  Definitely yes.  It's all about the context.  

Think about it: there are tons of legal drugs, like OxyContin, Vicodin, Percocet, that pharmacies use all the time. They're controlled substances, but they're super helpful.  If we're okay with those, why not consider marijuana for its potential benefits?

It's not exactly like alcohol, though. Alcohol can be bad if you overdo it, and so can marijuana. But I think we should approach marijuana differently.  Maybe a gradual legalization process would be better, step by step, so it doesn't get out of hand.  We need to ditch the stigma surrounding marijuana first.  Once people see it's not the scary monster everyone thinks it is, they might use it responsibly.

Honestly, people have such a warped view of marijuana just because it's illegal. It's not like heroin or cocaine, you know?  If we get rid of that image, people could use it responsibly. And definitely for medical purposes!

I think the church has modernized to fit the 21st century. It's not as strict as it used to be. When I was younger, I went to church every Sunday in cute dresses, matching shoes and a purse.  I went to a private school and saw all my friends there on the weekends. Now, they have a special mass for teenagers that's only thirty minutes long.  People dress much more casually, especially in the summer, coming straight from the beach. Even at the morning masses, where I used to dress up, people wear jeans and khakis. It's definitely more relaxed. That's the biggest change I've noticed. As for other changes, I don't know much about the church's politics.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests, I don't think allowing female priests or married priests would have stopped these situations. Some married men become pedophiles too. It's a personal issue, not a matter of being able to marry or not. Priests choose to become priests, and if they want to be married while practicing their faith, maybe they should consider another religion. There are religions where priests can marry, like the one on the TV show "Seventh Heaven."  

I think pedophilia is often genetic. It's something people are born with, not something they choose. Marriage wouldn't change that.  If the church knew about these cases and tried to cover them up, that's terrible. But I don't think they always knew.

Okay, so, I get where they were going with the whole Iraq thing at first, but it was right after 9/11, and everyone was super shook up.  I think they used 9/11 as a way to justify going into Iraq, saying that Saddam Hussein had ties to Osama Bin Laden and weapons of mass destruction. Turns out, none of that was true, and that really rubs me the wrong way. The whole Iraq War just makes my blood boil.

Honestly, it feels like the Bush administration straight-up lied to the American people about everything. Even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN, has said he wasn't totally convinced by the evidence back then. To me, that's a huge betrayal of trust, something that should be impeachable.  It feels like they've just been disrespecting the Constitution ever since 9/11.  

I have a feeling they went into office wanting to go to war.  I remember reading a book by the Treasury Secretary, who basically said that Bush Jr. had a vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of his dad's dealings with him. And on top of that, I think Bush Jr. was hoping to secure more energy resources for the U.S. through the war.  It all feels very manipulative.

Look, I think it's gone on long enough.  Pulling out right now would probably cause a civil war and more deaths, though.  They're trying this thing with a coalition of neighboring countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to help restore order, but I'm not sure that's the best idea either. It's going to create problems with Iraq's sovereignty in the long run.

With the news I've seen, the Parliament doesn't seem to be doing much, and the Prime Minister doesn't really have any control.  Even that guy, Muqtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting not too long ago, his party now has a bunch of seats in Parliament. There are still so many radical groups fighting for power, and it's creating a lot of tension.

Ugh, the War in Iraq... it's a mess. I mean, it's not even officially a war, which is kinda weird. It feels like it was all about revenge for 9/11, like we just wanted to hit back at whoever we thought did it.  I don't really follow the details, but it seems like we're just stuck there now, trying to build a democracy and get our hands on some oil. But honestly, it's just making everyone angry.  

Trying to force democracy on them is taking forever, and if we leave, they'll be mad because they feel like we messed everything up. It's a lose-lose situation.  

I don't know, it's a hard topic. It feels like we're using our military power to show off, like we're bigger and better. But it doesn't feel right.  We didn't even officially declare war, and now it's dragging on and on. It's making Bush look bad, like another Vietnam situation where everything feels pointless.

Plus, there are so many families with loved ones over there. I want them to come home safe, but it also feels wrong to stay and change their culture. It's a whole mess. I think this thing is going to keep going for years and years.

Listen, I really don't think it's right for the government to make laws about this.  The Constitution clearly states the separation of church and state, and I believe trying to enforce any kind of control over religious practices goes against that.  It feels like picking sides, favoring one church's beliefs over another.  For example, most Catholics and Christians are against this, except for maybe in some areas like Boston.  I just don't think it's the government's place to decide what churches can and can't do.

Separation of church and state is a huge part of what allows for religious freedom in the US. Even though there's talk about making an amendment, I think that's completely wrong.  It would go against what's already in the Constitution and would be one of the few amendments that actually restricts people rather than the government.

I don't believe the federal government, or any government for that matter, should get involved. It seems like this push for an amendment is just based on personal beliefs, specifically the president's Catholic views. It feels like he's favoring one religion over all others.  This decision should be left up to the churches themselves.  There's no real reason for a government amendment beyond personal opinions. I don't see how it would affect the economy or anything else, and it might even have a positive impact on society.

Okay, so the Iraq War...  Honestly, I don't think the government was completely upfront with the American people about why we went to war. Before invading Iraq, they tried to link it to the 9/11 attacks, even though they weren't really connected. They played on people's emotions after 9/11 and used that outrage to justify the invasion in 2003.

Personally, I'm against war, especially preemptive strikes. The Iraq War feels a lot like a repeat of Vietnam. We should have learned from our past mistakes. So many American soldiers have died, and it's just horrible.  

The US removed Iraq's government, but they weren't prepared for the chaos that would follow. They were trying to install a democracy, similar to what happened in Vietnam, where we tried to push out communists and promote democracy. But the US government should have known that wouldn't be easy. It's a long and hard process, and there's no guarantee of a clear victory.

In both Vietnam and Iraq, there were always going to be insurgents, even if some people supported the US intervention. It's hard to fight a war against your own citizens. 

I think the government wasn't prepared for any of this. They should have planned for all possible outcomes before going to war.  We're still there in 2006, and American troops are still dying. They're trying to train Iraqi troops and police forces, but it's a slow process.

The US government made it seem like the war would be quick and successful, but it's far from it.  It takes time to build a new government and a stable society, as we saw in our own country's history.

So, the war in Iraq is a tough situation. We've been there for so long, it's hard to just walk away. But at what cost? How many more American lives are we willing to sacrifice? 

It also makes you wonder why we're only focused on Iraq. Why not other countries with problems, like North Korea? I think the oil issue plays a big part. We need to ask ourselves if this is really about freedom and democracy, or if it's about controlling resources.

Remember, they said Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but we never found any. Yet, we aren't doing anything about North Korea, which we know has these weapons.  

I just hope the war ends soon and that there is peace in Iraq. But I'm not sure that's going to happen anytime soon.

Okay, so I'm totally for gay marriage. Always have been.  I just think it's a personal preference, something that's becoming more and more clear is biological, not sociological. It doesn't make sense to take away someone's rights because of something they can't control. It feels wrong to me. I've always supported gay marriage. 

And honestly, politics and government shouldn't be involved. It's not a state or national issue; it's about personal relationships and families. Like, in my neighborhood back home, there are a few openly gay couples who aren't married because they can't be. They live their lives just like any other family though — walk their dogs, hang out, you know?  It's frustrating that Bush is trying to define marriage in his own way. It just seems ridiculous.

There's so much research now showing that being gay might be biological, a chemical thing in the brain, not something you choose. It's like being predisposed to something, not a result of your upbringing.

Besides the obvious, it feels like marriage is different for gay couples.  A straight couple can just elope to Vegas if they want, but a gay couple wanting to get married makes headlines.  It shouldn't be such a big deal. It's a private matter, not something that needs to be public.

Okay, so, here's the deal: anything you post online becomes public knowledge.  It's out there for everyone to see. As an RA, I've had to deal with this firsthand.  Whatever you put on the internet  shapes how people perceive you.  If you're talking about blowing things up or shootings, someone is going to take notice. You can't just put that kind of stuff out into the world. The internet is global; if you're friends with someone on Myspace, they'll see your posts.  

The school didn't magically receive a bulletin; someone went to them with this information. They have to act on these kinds of threats because, imagine if something happened, and they could have prevented it. 

But it's a tricky situation because you don't always know what's serious and what's just someone messing around.  It could be a harmless joke gone wrong, like a sociology class experiment, or it could be something truly dangerous.  

In our school's case, someone overheard a conversation, reported it, and the school investigated. They looked at the student's Facebook page because some things he posted, while maybe intended as a joke, became very concerning in light of the situation.

The bottom line is, when you share things online, there's no real expectation of privacy. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it. You can't control how people interpret things or what they take seriously.

I don't think school officials should be friending their students on social media and snooping through their profiles.  It's a violation of privacy.  But if someone brings something to their attention, they have to take it seriously.

I feel like the war has dragged on way too long. At the beginning, the intention seemed good – to bring democracy to a country lacking fair political systems. But I think we've lost sight of that original goal. Now it feels like we're just fighting to prove our global dominance. 

Honestly, I have doubts about the initial motives too. There were those past conflicts between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein that might have played a role.

If the goal was to help a country oppressed by a dictator achieve democracy, that would be a justifiable reason. But if personal vendettas were involved, that wouldn't be right.

Regardless, the war has gone on far too long. We made our point in the initial months, demonstrating our military strength. But years later, it just feels excessive.

I believe our original purpose has become muddled and distorted. It seems like we're fighting for the sake of fighting, needing a decisive victory, instead of for a clear, achievable goal.

It's time to end this war. Their government and officials need to take responsibility for their own country. We've already drained our economy, spending billions on a conflict that's lost its meaning.

We have pressing issues at home – poverty, inadequate infrastructure, healthcare – that deserve our attention and funding. Spending billions on a prolonged war that has lost its purpose is draining our resources from these critical areas. 

We need to stop this war and invest in our own people and our own future.

Can I ask something to make sure I understand? It sounds like this situation was stopped because someone saw something online, right?

Okay, okay.

Honestly, I don't think that's an invasion of privacy.  On sites like Myspace, if you put information out there, it's basically public knowledge. I get that on Myspace you need to be friends with someone to see their profile, but if you accept someone as a friend, you're giving them permission to see your stuff.

So, if you post something online, you should know that lots of people might see it. If I think that in this case, someone seeing that information online and preventing a tragedy was a good thing.

That's a tough one though.  I mean, you can't have one person constantly checking everyone's profiles at school to prevent something bad from happening. But then, if they start focusing on "bad kids" and looking at their profiles, that feels like discrimination.

I don't think it would be fair to have someone's job be to monitor people's profiles all day.  But maybe it depends on the situation. Were they looking for evidence of something specific, or were they just randomly browsing? It's hard to say.


I don't personally have a Myspace, but I do have a Facebook. It does worry me that there are creepy people out there who can see things about me. I saw a news story once about a guy who could easily find people's information online. He got a girl's screen name from her profile and started talking to her on instant messenger. He managed to get her to meet him in less than a minute. 

Personally, I would never do that, but I've had people in my classes message me on Facebook even though I don't recognize their screen names. They know it's me, though. It's strange because they seem to know a lot about me - my interests, what I look like, even my class schedule and who my friends are. They can see all sorts of photos too. I try to be careful about what I post, but at the same time, Facebook is supposed to be a way to connect with friends. It's a tricky balance. I only accept friend requests from people I know, but you never really know who can see what.

I heard my roommate talking about how her high school banned Myspace. That seemed a little weird to me. I don't know if that's really a privacy issue, but I'm not sure how the school has the right to tell students they can't use Myspace.

Hmm, you know, talking about the Iraq War feels kinda hypocritical. I hate to jump on the bandwagon of people who say they were against it from the start, but I was.  It's not really a big deal anymore though, because everyone pretty much agrees it was a bad idea except for those in power who don't want to admit they were wrong.  

Look at the polls - they've done them everywhere, in the US, Iraq, even globally, and  it's pretty clear: 75-80% of the world thinks it was a bad call. Eighty percent of Iraqis feel the same way, and even 70% of US troops over there think we should pull out within a year.  

Honestly, it's been a mess from day one.  It was a disaster before we even went in, and pulling out is going to be another disaster.  

There's just no easy solution when it comes to the Middle East. It's a clash of cultures - the US and the Middle East are just too different.  This administration, and previous ones, think they can just force democracy on a region where it doesn't fit. It's just not how those people want to live.

Sure, Saddam was a bad guy, but you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country that's going to turn into a complete disaster.  It's like quicksand. I don't even know what to say about it anymore.

I don't see any reason to stay there. I'm sure the administration has some hopeful ideas about why it's better to stay, but I haven't heard any legitimate reasons. 

If they want to pull out gradually over a year or so, I wouldn't mind that. But I just don't see why we shouldn't leave now. 

I read that 80% of Iraqis want us gone within a year, and a quarter want us to leave right now. These are the people we're trying to help, and they're telling us to leave. Maybe they know better.

At least if we ask them if we should leave and they say yes, then it's not on us if things go wrong. We can say, "We were going to stay, but you guys made the decision to leave."

Maybe that would make us the "good guys" - not really, no, never truly. But it would be better than where we are now.

Yeah, I definitely think gender discrimination is still a problem in the United States. 

And it's not just about women. I think it depends on the specific field you're in. 

For women, overall, I feel like they face a tougher time because of the "glass ceiling." Even though equality is supposed to exist, a lot of people still struggle to accept having a woman in a leadership position, especially if it's over a man. This is because of how society has been for so long.

Women often hit a point where they're qualified for a promotion, but the board might not choose them because of the historical stereotype that women aren't usually in leadership roles. 

It's similar for men too, though. Think about things like the fashion industry or staying at home as a parent. 

It's uncommon for a man to stay at home while the woman works. People sometimes judge that because society expects men to be the primary earners. But maybe the husband wants to be with the kids, and the wife has the better job. It can be really hard for them because society doesn't see it as the "normal" arrangement.

And in fashion, straight men can sometimes struggle to be taken seriously.  It might sound weird, but it's probably because people associate fashion with women. If a man has a "typical" lifestyle and he's in fashion, people might wonder if he really understands women's fashion. 

Basically, I think gender discrimination exists in different ways depending on your field.

Changing it is tough because society has a set way of thinking, and while we've come a long way from the 1800s, change takes time.  

The good news is, we're seeing progress. More women are becoming CEOs and being accepted in the business world. We're also seeing more stay-at-home dads being accepted because people are realizing that sometimes it works better that way. 

It's all about showing the positive qualities of people who are stereotyped. If you force things, people resist. 

We're at a good point now where things are slowly changing, but it takes time.

They didn't actually legalize marijuana; they decriminalized it.  That means it's not a criminal offense anymore, more like a traffic ticket. You get cited instead of arrested and booked.  I think that if someone gets caught with it and gets cited, it can still have consequences for things like job interviews. Those kinds of negative impacts are usually the worst part of having a drug charge.  Even with decriminalization, people worry about those future repercussions.  

But on the other hand, it costs a lot of money to arrest, book, and house people, plus court costs, public defenders, and the state attorney’s office. All that adds up. So when cities are struggling financially, some aren't willing to make that change, even if it would free up money for things like public education, social programs, and food assistance. Some communities just strongly oppose marijuana and don't want to decriminalize it.  

Places like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, might be fine with it because it frees up resources. I think it's important because marijuana shouldn't just be readily available everywhere. There are lots of reasons for that, but the financial aspect is a big one too.

If it were fully legalized, it could be like cigarettes, sold in gas stations and smoked openly. That might lead to more people smoking and driving. Plus, marijuana is still seen as taboo in many places and contexts. Seeing it out in the open like that could feel awkward for some people.

Alcohol probably has more immediate negative effects on motor skills, but for a lot of people, marijuana has a bigger impact on their lifestyle overall. Both have their downsides, and everyone reacts differently. Some people can handle moderation, while others go overboard. It's hard to generalize because people react so differently to substances.

I'd say, yeah, there are good and bad things about being Catholic.  They've got a lot of traditions they've stuck with for ages, and that can be nice.  It's comforting to have those roots. But, sometimes it feels like they're stuck in the past and don't adapt well to change.  Like, a lot of Catholics feel they *have* to go to church every week, and there are strict rules about everything. And, honestly, it feels like they judge people pretty harshly if they don't follow the rules perfectly. 

They don't seem very accepting of people who aren't exactly like them, either.  For example, my dad was Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't even marry them in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion.  Isn't that supposed to be a loving religion?  It seems hypocritical to preach love but then turn around and reject people because they don't fit in.

It's like, they tell you to love everyone, but their actions don't always match those words.  They cling to old rules even though they don't seem to make sense in the modern world.

Now, about priests getting married... I think it'd be good if they could.  But, I don't know if it would really stop the bad stuff that happens sometimes.  Those issues are way more complicated than just whether or not a priest is married. It's a sad thing that happens, and I don't think marriage would magically fix it.

I'm still trying to figure out where I stand on this whole marriage equality issue. I honestly can't say if one side is right or wrong because it's such a complex problem. It's a real tightrope walk between separating church and state and figuring out what marriage truly means. 

It's tough because defining marriage without upsetting anyone is nearly impossible. I'm not sure if the government should be involved in defining marriage at all, especially when it's seen as a religious sacrament.  Think about it – the government doesn't get involved in how people practice their religion, so why should they dictate who can get married? 

Maybe it's simpler to just see it as civil unions.  It's about two people committing to each other, regardless of their beliefs or sexual orientation. The government shouldn't care about the specifics of the ceremony, just that two people want to be together. 

If all the states could agree on a fair solution, they should push for a federal law. But, changing the Constitution to ban gay marriage? That just seems extreme. The Constitution shouldn't be amended for something like this, even if it's important to some people. It's not a big enough issue to warrant such a drastic change.

Growing up in a Christian household, the topic of homosexuality is a bit complicated for me.  I have lots of gay friends, so it's not a black-and-white issue. While I personally don't agree with that lifestyle, I believe it should be legal. I don't think it should be a nationwide debate, though.  

I think each state should decide for itself whether or not to legalize same-sex marriage.  Some states lean Democratic, and those are more likely to support gay marriage. If you live in a state that's okay with it, you're probably going to be fine with their decision. And honestly, if you choose to live somewhere, you kind of accept their views, right?

I think everyone deserves equal opportunities, regardless of their sexual orientation. So, I feel strongly that the legality of gay marriage should be left up to the states.

That said, I don't think President Bush should have the power to ban gay marriage nationwide. It should be up to the individual states to decide what's best for them. He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't be making that kind of decision for everyone.

Plus, he's leaving office soon.  If a Democratic president comes in and wants to lift the ban, it'll just go back and forth.  It's better to let each state make its own choice. After all, they're the ones who'll have to live with the consequences.

Okay, so, I get where they're coming from. I mean, Myspace is basically like a public bulletin board. If you post something there, you're putting it out for everyone to see.  It doesn't matter if you're using your school's name or not, anyone can find it, even from their own homes.  

I think the school officials were right to look at it. If it helps prevent something terrible like a school shooting, that's important. Protecting the students is the school's job, and if they had information about a potential threat, they had a responsibility to act.

It's different if they're just snooping around looking for kids drinking or smoking. That's an invasion of privacy. But if they have a legitimate reason, like preventing harm, then I think it's okay.

It's just like with emails. You wouldn't want to say something bad about someone in an email because you never know who might read it.  Everything you put online can come back to haunt you later.

It's a tricky situation.  It's good to be able to express yourself online, but you have to be careful what you say. It's a public space, and anything you post can be seen by anyone, even the school.

Okay, so, about the war... At first, I was totally on board. Nine/Eleven hit me personally, you know? I wanted revenge, to make them pay for what they did. But looking back, I think we were all just so emotional after that, we didn't really think things through. We went in unprepared, without a solid plan, and honestly, I think it backfired.

I used to be all for it, but now I'm completely against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. It feels like the people over there are so caught up in fighting each other that they'll always be at each other's throats, regardless of us being there.  

It's hard, because of Nine/Eleven, I've kind of just checked out. I don't care what happens to them anymore. It's like, they can't even get along with each other, how are they going to get better?  Sometimes I don't even think they're human, the way they fight.

We went in blind. We had no idea what we were facing. Their idea of war is so different from ours, they're just savage. I don't think they want to improve their country, they just want us out. And maybe that's okay. Maybe we should just leave it alone. 

I think we were mostly just angry and fueled by revenge. We didn't think about the long-term consequences or how they'd react. President Bush, he probably felt pressured, like we had no choice but to declare war on Iraq after what happened.

But honestly, we should have had a better plan. We were all over the place, with no clear goals or unity. Maybe if we'd gone in with a clear strategy, things would have been different. I just feel like we were all so emotionally driven, and that's what we ended up creating over there. 

I don't think we're the ones to change them. They're probably always going to be like this. I just don't know what else to say. This whole thing has dragged on for too long. We've made some progress, but not enough to justify staying.  

I think no matter how long we stay, things will fall apart as soon as we leave. We can't be there forever, and I think we're only hurting ourselves by staying.
